title: Aggregativity: Reductive Heuristics for Finding Emergence ()
Groups with minds of their own ()
tldr: "Pettit discusses the discursive dilemma, or when a group is faced with ensuring, or not, the consistency of opinions/beliefs among its members. In the diachronic case, it becomes harder and harder as individuals can change how they feel about earlier collective decisions. Pettit is talking about how groups who need to form a collective decision in specific contexts such as the court or deciding on public goods, or group rationality/intentionality, should be conferred the status of intentional subject (albeit a weird one)."

title: Rationality in Collective Action ()
tldr: "If supra-individual _agency_ makes sense, we need to review rational choice theory. "

title: Collective Action and Rational Choice Explanations ()
What are social groups? Their metaphysics and how to classify them ()
tldr: "Pessimistic about our ability to have a neat typology... Social groups are enormously diverse, but show how we can investigate their natures nonetheless."

title: The ontology of social groups ()
tldr: "Instead of asking what is a social group, more useful to ask what function the concept of a social group does or can serve for us...less ontological, more pragmatic. Also giving up on a more general conception of what a social group is."
